titleStmt.title: Private letter. The Emperor Aurelian and the Corrector Firmus in a private context
titleStmt.author: unknown (a legenionary?)

msContents.summary: Private letter. Neither the name of the sender nor that of the recipient has survived, but it is clear that the sender has been appointed as a legionary by Firmus, a corrector of Egypt. The sender seems to object to something connected with this appointment (ll. 4-50, possibly because he is being sent to Syria (ll. 5-7) at the time when the emperor Aurelian was there. After a few lines obscured by damage (9-13), the writer apparently reports that his military title has not been included yet in the registers of the legio secunda Traiana Fortis Aureliana. This legion in this period was stationed in Nikopolis, near Alexandria. Given the circumstances and since the papyrus comes from Karanis, it is tempting to speculate that the recipient (probably a parent or sibling) lived there. If the sender is the legionary mentioned in the letter, then perhaps he is writing from Nikopolis. Other possibilities, of course, cannot be excluded.

condition.ab: The small light brown papyrus contains parts of twenty one lines written against the fibers (verso) on a recycled piece of papyrus. After l. 2 a left margin of approximately 1 cm is visible until line 21 of the extant text. No right margin survives. If the restoration of lines 2-4 is correct, then three to four letters are missing there. This gap becomes progressively bigger as the papyrus is broken off irregularly on the right side. Neither the beginning nor the end of the document has survived and it is not possible to determine how much is missing. The other side of the papyrus (recto) contains poor remains of what appears to be a tax-list written upside down in relation to the text on the verso.

handDesc.p: The text is written in a rather small neat hand in a rather narrow column.

provenance.p: Karanis, Herakleidou meris, Arsinoite nome, province of Egypt
